page.title: 04EGLOSKERRY CHURCH
page.content: The church takes its name from Eglos = church, and Keri.(St.Keri was one of 26 children of St. Brychan from Wales.) St. Keri also established a chapel between the River Ottery and Kensey. St. Keri's missionary work took place between 500-600 A.D.Until 1540 the parish was served by a priest from Launceston priory.The Register only began in 1547.The Bishop of Exeter is recorded as consecrating a church at Egloskerry in 1222.Remains of this building may be seen in the blocked up north door,the carving over the inside of the south door and the dragon snapping its tail over the outside of the north door.Most of the the church is 15th. century except for the north wall,transept,font and piscina which are Norman.The south aisle was added in 1622 by Sir John Speccott of Penheale Manor.(Cont. p.5)
